author: jan Pensamin
alente.author_verbatim: a proposal for a final nimisin: "alente". Etymology "ale + ante". It means the set of every possible human concept subtracted from the set of concepts already covered by established toki pona words weighted by their relative usage. So then you can shoot down anyone proposing another nimisin with "that's just alente, but even nicher!" /j

translations.commentary: Coined humorously as the "final nimisin" - any newer word would semantically be included in alente, so it can be refuted for being "alente but even nicher".
translations.definition: the set of concepts expressed by established toki pona words, subtracted from the set of every possible concept, such that every concept not already expressed by an existing toki pona word is expressed
translations.etymology: ale ante: toki pona, everything else

translations.definition: (particle) [placed after the main sentence, introducing a context phrase]
translations.etymology: la: toki pona, (indicate context for a following sentence)

author: wuwojiti Heav, jan Pensa, jan Kita
ja.author_verbatim:
.. ja2 **ja** - *post-ku*: marks the end of a preverb (or preposition, with lu)

Makes it possible to make anything into a preverb without ambiguity.
> *mi tawa telo e kasi*: I'm moving a plant towards water.
> *mi tawa ja telo e kasi*: I'm going (in order) to water the plants.
Can be used to make composite preverbs by including multiple words before the ja.
> *mi wile mute ja sona e ni*: I really want to know this.
Can be stacked.
> *mi open ja olin ja telo e kasi*: I'm starting to love watering the plants.
Can optionally be used with existing preverbs to clarify them.
> *mi wile ja kama ja sona* = *mi wile kama sona.*
> *mi olin ja kama ja sona e ijo sin* = *mi olin ja kama sona e ijo sin* = I love to learn new things.
All preverbs before the last ja should be marked by ja.
> *mi wile ja tawa ja tawa musi* ‚â† *mi wile tawa ja tawa musi.*

Can be used with lu (see `... lu`) to make composite prepositions.
> *soko li lu ante mute ja leko*: Mushrooms are very different to squares.
> *mi pali e ni lu kepeken wawa ja luka mi*: I made this by vigorously using my hands.
> *pakala ni li kama lon lu kepeken pi ike lili ja ilo kule*: This mess was made via somewhat bad usage of a paintbrush.

translations.commentary: Can also be combined with lo to mark modified or compound prepositions, marking the end of a preposition marked by lo and the start of the prepositional object.
translations.definition: (particle) [marks the previous word(s) as a single preverb]

translations.commentary: In a poll in 2002, "jalan" was proposed as a replacement for "noka". However, it failed to get enough votes.
translations.definition: foot, leg [polled as a replacement for noka in 2002]
translations.etymology: jalan: Finnish, afoot; jalka: Finnish, foot

translations.commentary: Not coined directly, but developed out of repeated use in the early ma pona pi toki pona Discord server community. jans was repeatedly used because of the humor in adding an English plural suffix to a Toki Pona word.

translations.commentary: Coined indepentently multiple times over several years, non-wuwojiti variant of the word jipi.

josuta is not the same as ko. or kiwen. or telo. It is its own thing. josuta covers the concepts of elasticity, the quality of things that are rubbery, and stretchy; elasticity. author: jan Seli
jume.author_verbatim: isipin is kinda dumb so here's a better nimisin: jume, dream

translations.commentary: Experimental, to see how the meaning could be expanded, but never actually used. No set of meanings was ever settled on before stopping the experiment, but one potential meaning the creator particularly liked was "fantasy" or "unreality", without a negative connotation.

niko

also partially coined because there isn't a common toki pona word that starts with the syllable "ju" and i don't like any of the sandbox ones that do lol [...]

author: jan Posuke
ka.author_verbatim:
.. ka ka - ~toki sapin~ particle
    ‚Üê toki pona,  kama
It is the same as "li" but has the meaning of "tenpo kama" built into it.
So, "akesi ka moku" is the same as "tenpo kama la akesi li moku"

translations.definition: (replacement for li, marked for future tense)
translations.etymology: ka: toki sapin, (future tense marker); kama: toki pona, coming

author: qpaper
ka1.author_verbatim:
üì£ ***ka*** *~nimisin~* ‚Äî question marker
  ‚Üê Japanese „Åã *ka* (question marker)
usage: `[sentence] ka` 
example: `sina pilin pona` (you feel good)
                  `sina pilin pona ka` (do you feel good?)

translations.commentary:
Recoined indepentently multiple times over several years."
Originally created for toki sapin, a short-lived unfinished tokiponido created in January 2021 by jan Posuke. It survived through notes in ma pona pi toki pona, where it was the first thing that came up for "ka".
Created as part of a set with "so" for the past tense, "te" for the present tense, and contractions "miso", "mite", and "mika". Only "ka" has seen significant mention outside of toki sapin.
Borrowed from tuki tiki as a replacement for the deprecated konwe.
translations.definition: living thing, moving being, creature; life, alive
translations.etymology: ka: tuki tiki, being, person, creature, alive; jan: toki pona, human being, person, somebody
kalama: toki pona, make sound. sound, noise, voice; arr: English, (imitation of pirates)

translations.commentary: the orthography of that word is not fixed and any ‚Äúwuwojiti‚Äù is not considered a mistake. In fact, basically anything after kalapis‚Ä¶ can be altered and it would still be considered the same word (so go ahead and have fun with kalapisituwi, kalapisituje, kalapisu‚Ä¶, or any form that pleases you).
translations.definition: scam, utterly nonsensical, muddled and confused (often on purpose)

author: kolisin
kepa.author_verbatim:
I have a few nimisin that I‚Äôve been cooking on for the past month, so I‚Äôll share a few over some time. this one is my best one so far in my opinion
:nimisin: ***kepa*** - etymology is a priori. pattern, order, series, sequence, to arrange, to organize. this overlaps with the semantic spaces of nasin and sike a bit. this word also can be used as an antonym of sorts to jaki and nasa. kepa as a content word is mostly useful when combined with other words. some examples would be "tenpo kepa" (rhythm), "kepa pi kasi kule" (bouquet/flower arrangement), "kepa pakala" (disarray, chaos). I also like to experiment with using it as a preposition that means something along the lines of "and then". some examples include "mi moku e kili li kepa tawa" (I ate fruit and then I walked), "mi en kepa sina li sitelen e nimi mi" (I will write my name and then you will write your name [nimi mi being used as "our names"]), and "jan lili li luka e soweli e kepa waso" (The child pet the animals and then the birds)

translations.commentary: Semantically, "kepa" describes a group or the state of a group rather than the state of one thing in a group.
translations.definition: pattern, order, sequence, series, rhythm; arrangement, organization, decluttering; weaving, knitting

translations.commentary: Coined as a shortened version of kepeken by jan Tomen in 2017. Did not see significant use until 2020.
translations.etymology: kepeken: toki pona, to use, by means of, with

translations.commentary: Part of a system with sunta to express the colors seen by someone with tritanopia (blue-yellow colorblindness).
translations.etymology: kule: toki pona, color, pigment. category, genre, flavor. colorful, diverse; sewi: toki pona, up, top, above, highest part. divine, sacred, supernatural. awesome, inspiring, excelling

translations.etymology: mollusk: English, Invertebrae related to snails, slugs, mussels, octopi (scientific nomenclature); mollusca: Latin, thin shelled

translations.definition: relationship, correlation, commonality; cross, knot, junction, intersection; to overlap, to fold; to overstep, to exceed to a point
translations.etymology: ng√£ t∆∞: Vietnamese, crossroads, four-way intersection

translations.commentary: Meant to be antonymous to the 'cover, layer of privacy' meanings of 'len'. It can be applied both literally and metaphorically.
translations.definition: transparent material/object, lack of privacy; clear, transparent, unobstructed; to make clear, to make transparent, to remove obstructions
translations.etymology: len: toki pona, cloth, fabric, clothing. secret, hidden, covered

translations.commentary: Intended as an alt to esun which implies that non-mutually-beneficial relationships are not real relationships.
translations.definition: connected, related, joined; complementary, mutual; exchange
translations.etymology: n·ªëi: Vietnamese, to join, to add, to unite, to connect. to continue, to carry on, to perpetuate

translations.definition: (word reserved for future use by Sonja Lang)

translations.commentary: Coined by jan Sonja after she was asked for a word beginning with "nu", for use in sitelen pona cartouches using nasin sitelen kalama.
translations.etymology: nujum: Malay, astrology, fortune-telling, predicting the future. fortune-teller, oracle. star

translations.commentary: Though it may have many possible origins, it was first coined in a small group chat. It is mostly used as a variant of the toki pona words "oke" and "ke"
translations.etymology: okie: English, okay; okay: English, okay

translations.commentary: this is a hard word to explain and you've got to use it right. It's pretty much linked to anything you could use "oh l√†  l√†" or "ouh l√† l√†" for. But because it's now a full-fledged toki pona content word, it got even more powerful and versatile. It can be used for joy, surprise, excitement, admiration, compassion, empathy, sadness, disappointment, and even to show you‚Äôre interested in someone romantically. However, it's equally important (or more) to know when to *not* use the word, you wouldn‚Äôt want to commit a faux-pas!

translations.definition: (proper name) a song by jan Usawi, (literally) "o moku e kala ike" (eat a bad fish)
translations.etymology: o moku e kala ike: toki pona, 'eat a bad fish', wishing somebody harm instead of well; o moku e kala pona: toki pona, 'eat a good fish', wishing somebody well

author: jan inwin
omen.author_verbatim: canonize *'o¬∑m¬∑e¬∑m'* (‚Üê 'o moli e mi') into an actuall tp word *'omen'*, meaning "sarcasm, sarcastic"

translations.commentary: Originally an initialism of "o moli e mi" ("omem"); compare the formations of "peto" and "kuntu".
translations.etymology: o moli e mi: toki pona, 'kill me', express exasperation or frustration sarcastically

translations.commentary:
This word is deprecated by the creator; it is considered part of the "toki oni" tokiponido instead.
The pronunciation of the second syllable was due to personal preferences of the creator, not modern Greek.
translations.definition: dream, daydream, imaginative play, vision, mystical state; to entrance

author: ko Luna
onono.author_verbatim:
alright everone, i've come to nimisin. except it's not just any nimisin, it's one that i've put a bit of work into and have grown very fond of.

nimi: onono
meaning: emergency, attention, urgent; primarily an interjection
sitelen: triangle with exclamation point

while one could use it as a content word, the main purpose of onono is as an interjection at the beginning of a sentence, especially to call attention and convey a sense of urgency. in a way, it's a "set the context" nimi more than a "has a meaning" nimi. ideally, this nimi is useful as rarely as possible. but like a fire extinguisher, you would have it in case you need it, not because you use it often enough.

there are certainly plenty other ways that you could describe an onono situation without onono, but that's not the point. the point of the nimi is that having a single word that is immediately recognizable is extra beneficial in that particular situation, especially with how context would be as against you as it gets in that moment.

i've already been using onono in my works the past several months (albeit not many times due to its nature) and i really like it so far. it just feels to me that "emergency" is one of the most important things to be able to communicate, so it would make sense to have a dedicated word for that purpose, no matter how narrow that purpose is.

and of course, obviously don't use conlangs in an actual emergency. though if you were in a tpt environment, onono can also convey "what i'm about to say is probably really important so don't jump to kokosila'ing me if i start using a different language."

(if i don't respond it's because i used up all my spoons battling my "presenting creation" anxiety and "public discord" anxiety)

author: smoothied
opasan.author_verbatim: opasan ‚Äì ~post-pu, humorous~ talented, brilliant, incredible, amazing, show stopping, spectacular, never the same, completely not ever been done before, totally unique, very very gay, opossum

translations.definition: (interjection) bruh; expression of disbelief, exasperation, or excitement

translations.etymology: pakala: toki pona, broken, damaged, harmed, destroyed

translations.definition: 1. pan palisa Panke | 2. something typical of French culture | 3. calque-ing the French language when speaking toki pona.

translations.commentary: Several (different?) people in 2019-2021 weirdly kept putting "papa" in their Reddit / Facebook posts, seemingly to promote it as a word to other people. It caused a backlash, with other people criticising the coinage, and coining other meanings for "papa".

translations.definition: good, easy; simple, relaxed, peaceful, uncomplicated
translations.etymology: facile: Acadian French, easy; facila: Esperanto, easy
–±—Ä–∞—Ç (brat): Serbo-Croatian, brother; brata: Tok Pisin, sibling or cousin of the same gender; brother: English, brother

author: jan Sonja
pela.author_verbatim: pela could be a nimi sin for dog

translations.commentary: A reference to Sacha Baron Cohen's interview with Noah Chomsky.
Originally an initialism of "pana e telo oko"; compare the formations of "omen" and "kuntu".
translations.etymology: pana e telo oko: toki pona, (incomplete sentence) 'give eye-water', to cry
pipi: toki pona, bug, insect, arachnid

translations.definition: something that is supposed to be ‚Äúkikolo‚Äù but isn't
translations.etymology: kikolo: toki pona; pipo: toki pona

author: jan Majeka
pokasi.author_verbatim:
<:nimisin:743741432350769152> **pokasi** poggies, pog; an interjection of excitement; epic, cool, amazing, exciting,
Ety{English <poggies>}
Exmpl: kijetesantkalu kala li pokasi a

translations.definition: poggies, pog, poggers (interjection indicating excitement); epic, cool, amazing, exciting

author: jan Kisinja
polinpin.author_verbatim:
Noun
‚Ä¢Bowling pin
Adjective
‚Ä¢Bowling pin like
Verb
‚Ä¢To be a Bowling pin

translations.commentary: From the time management method developed by Francesco Cirillo in Berlin in the 1980s, for which people often used tomato-shaped timers. In ku, "pomotolo" was given as one of the translations of "tomato", presumably due to speakers misusing or misunderstanding the word.
Occasionally comes up as a jokish corruption of "pona" (especially in a phrase "toki poni").
translations.definition: pony (of or relating to the My Little Pony franchise)

author: waso Pini
positu.author_verbatim:
positu - the life, universe, and everything else /ref
I havent even read hitchhikers guide I just know that

translations.definition: the life, universe, and everything else
blue, blueish, indigo, navy blue, ultramarine
translations.etymology: blue: English, blue; laso: toki pona, blue, green

saja.author_verbatim: saja is my personal nimi sin for trees and wood

author: rose
salu.author_verbatim:
#1725441 üì£ salu ‚Äì ~post-ku~ comfort, security, safety, stability; attention, care, caution
   ‚Üê Latin salus 'safety, security'

translations.commentary: üí≠ Intended as an experiment in its current form, and is not meant for widespread use at this time. Meant to be used alongside a nasin that does not use either ike or pona to express value judgements (especially morality). These words are often used in a way that ignores the reasoning behind the judgement. The goal of this experimental nasin is to promote mindfulness about value itself, translating mere reaction into introspection and explanation. ‚ö†Ô∏è Because of the stated attachment to this particular nasin pi toki pona, it should be noted that using salu and pona/ike as good/bad at the same time goes against the point of the word's creation, and that salu is redundant in this circumstance. If you are using one, you should not use the other.
translations.definition: comfort, security, safety, stability; attention, care, caution

translations.commentary: Coined in reference to jan Samu, a Facebook user who attempted to propose a new word.
translations.etymology: jan Samu: toki pona, jan Samu

author: waso Netun
se1.author_verbatim: se is a reflexive pronoun and also means "one's own (thing)"

translations.commentary: sikeko is a common misspelling from tokiponists who believe "sikako" derives from "sike ko".
Coined in reference to the Travis Scott song ‚ÄòSicko Mode‚Äô.
translations.definition: on a higher tier/plane, enlighten(ed), epic; to an exceedingly great extent

author: jan Kita
silapa.author_verbatim: :nimisin: ***silapa*** ‚Äì giraffe; to make life even harder for sitelen pona font makers by introducing a vertically extendable glyph

translations.commentary:
Customarily written on multiple lines with a long "neck" composed of the letter "i" (originally the first "a"), like so:
si
 i
 ilapa

author: spad0103
sipi.author_verbatim: I thought of another word which would mean the "ego", "self", "own",because Toki Pona doesn't have reflexive voice and pronoun like inthe sentences "he's watching himself (and not somebody else)" or "Hetake his own(not her) hand". I called it "sipi" (as it is "sibi" inLatin). Then it would be "ona li lukin e sipi (pi ona)" (he watcheshis ego) and "ona li jo e luka sipi (pi ona)" (he takes his ego'shand). It would also be used to compound words like "egoism"(nasin/pilin sipi) and so on...What do you think?

translations.commentary: Proposed on a forum and quickly forgotten. Notable only for being an early non pu word proposal.
translations.etymology: sibi (dative reflexive pronoun): Latin, sibi (dative reflexive pronoun)

author: a friend of lipamanka
sipije.author_verbatim: I will be adding sipije to the font bc one of my friends coined it as a nimisin for autistic

translations.etymology: TBH creature: English; TBH: English, to be honest

author: ilo Powa
siwala.author_verbatim:
**siwala** ‚òÖ the quality of being outside of understanding but accepted as reality; the quality of being not wished to be understood by one for the benefits associated with not understanding
    ‚Üê Tagalog tiwal√† 'trust; faith (in someone or something); reliance, confidence, belief'

translations.definition: the quality of being outside of understanding but accepted as reality; the quality of being not wished to be understood by one for the benefits associated with not understanding
translations.etymology: tiwal√†: Tagalog, trust. faith (in someone or something). reliance, confidence, belief
lape: toki pona, sleep, rest; sleep: English, sleep

translations.commentary: Originally a sitelen pona glyph with no definition, created for fun and submitted to linja lipamanka. It grew popular after its inclusion in the font "sitelen seli kiwen", after which it has come to have a definition and seen some use.
translations.definition: soweli with relation to the snow or cold, soweli living in predominantly cold or snowy environments (often light-colored); arctic fox
translations.etymology: snowman: English, snowman; soweli: toki pona, fuzzy creature, land animal, beast

translations.commentary: May refer to a state prior to a kama.
translations.definition: pattern, constant, unchanged, unaltered, unaffected; instinct, habit, to use to, to tend to
translations.etymology: soler: Spanish, to use to, to tend to

translations.definition: [yes/no question marker, replacing the role of li]

translations.commentary: The typo was made by jan Sonja while writing ku. The absolute majority of the community does not treat it as a newly coined word.
translations.etymology: typo of sike: toki pona, circle, sphere, cycle

translations.definition: cyan, turquoise, teal, aquamarine, sky blue, light blue, light blueish
translations.etymology: cyan: English, the color between blue and green on the visible spectrum of light; laso: toki pona, blue, green

author: kolisin
sunta.author_verbatim:
<:nimisin:743741432350769152> **sunta** ‚Äî tritanopic color grouping, roughly seen as reds, pinks, and magentas, and roughly covers the perception of the wide range from warm violet, red, orange, and yellow
<- toki pona *suno* + *uta*

translations.commentary: Part of a system with kewe to express the colors seen by someone with tritanopia (blue-yellow colorblindness).
translations.etymology: suno: toki pona, light, shine, glow, radiance. sun, light source. brightness; uta: toki pona, mouth, lips, throat, consuming orifice
soweli: toki pona; suwi: toki pona

translations.commentary: Follows a semantically consistent pattern of "SUBJ li PV ta PRED" = "SUBJ li PV e [SUBJ li PRED]" or "[SUBJ li PRED] li PV". The top and bottom lines of the sitelen pona may be extended to the left around the pre-predicate word(s).

author: jan Sonja
tankala.author_verbatim: tankala or tenkala could be southeast

translations.commentary: One-off coinage by Sonja Lang after asking about neologisms for directions.

author: jan Pensa, jan Kita
tasun.author_verbatim: :nimisin: ***t(a+)sun*** ‚Äì dachshund; amount of `a` varies depending on physical length

translations.commentary: Coined as a challenge to font creators. The sitelen pona glyph can be extended horizontally. This is usually represented in Latin characters by additional a's, e.g. "taaasun".

**teki** ‚òÖ case, circumstance, situation, event, state (of affairs, being), status

translations.etymology: tenpo: toki pona, time, event, situation

author: jan Sonja
tenkala.author_verbatim: tankala or tenkala could be southeast

translations.commentary: Variant of tankala, suggested at the same time as an alternate tokiponization of the etymon.

translations.definition: focus, attention, concentrate, resolution, fineness; focus on

translations.commentary: The typo was made by jan Sonja while writing ku. The absolute majority of the community does not treat it as a newly coined word.
translations.etymology: typo of tomo: toki pona, home, room, house, building

translations.commentary: This word was only coined to make the spoonerism "poki tona" have a meaning.

translations.etymology: toki: toki pona, hello; OwO: emoticon, cat-like surprised face

author: soweli kina
uka.author_verbatim: I've actually kinda thought about the concept of a conlanguage that specifically encodes the deuteranopia color spectrum as default & so i like this idea

translations.commentary: Part of a system with kelo to express the colors seen by someone with protanopia or deuteranopia (red-green colorblindness).
translations.etymology: uta: toki pona, mouth, lips, throat, consuming orifice; kasi: toki pona, plant, vegetation. herb, leaf

umesu.author_verbatim: to amaze people by being on top of the musi Ako leaderboard

translations.etymology: Umeyz: Iqglic, to amaze (someone), surprise, impress
